content:
=== Game Rules ===
Game rules in natural language:
Below is an overview of what the rules tell us about the game:

• Game Type and Genre:
 – It’s a tile‐based, action–puzzle platformer reminiscent of classic titles like Spelunky or Boulder Dash.
 – The game features grid–based level navigation, falling objects (boulders), collectible items (diamonds), and various enemies.

• Game Mechanics:
 – The level is built out of different sprites such as walls, dirt, and background pieces that set up the environment.
 – The player controls an avatar (depicted using a Spelunky–like image) that can shoot a sword. The sword isn’t a permanent item but appears with a limited flicker effect.
 – There are collectible diamonds that boost your score. However, note that collecting them matters for later interactions.
 – Boulders fall (acting like missiles) and interact with other environmental pieces (like walls and dirt) and with the avatar. For example, if a boulder hits the avatar from above, it can kill the player (with a slight score penalty).
 – Various enemy sprites (such as generic enemies, crabs, and butterflies) roam the level. They interact in different ways (for instance, a butterfly hitting a crab transforms that enemy into a diamond and gives bonus points).
 – Some interactions cause a “stepBack” reaction (like boulders encountering walls or certain NPCs colliding with dirt/diamonds), preserving predictable physics that you can learn to work with.
 – Importantly, the exit door (colored green) won’t simply let you through—it has a built–in condition that interacts with your accumulated diamond resource. When the avatar reaches the door, the door checks your diamond count (with a set limit of 9) and “kills” the avatar if the resource condition isn’t met. This is the key to finishing the level.

• Objectives and Win/Loss Conditions:
 – The overall objective is to navigate through the level, gather resources (diamonds), defeat or avoid enemies and hazards (like falling boulders), and eventually reach the exit door.
 – Winning is determined by the removal of the exit door sprite (i.e. using it correctly under the right conditions) which triggers the win condition.
 – Losing happens if the avatar is killed (for example, by a boulder from above, enemy encounters, or failing the diamond requirement at the door).

• Overall Strategy:
 1. Move Carefully and Think Ahead – Since falling boulders and enemy movement create hazards, plan your path and time your moves so you aren’t caught off–guard.
 2. Use Your Sword Wisely – The sword resource is limited but effective. Use it to knock out obstacles like dirt or to defeat enemies at the right moment.
 3. Collect Diamonds with a Purpose – Diamonds boost your score, and some enemy interactions can even transform foes into extra diamonds. However, be aware of the door’s condition: if you have too many (more than 9), interacting with the door will kill the avatar.
 4. Understand Enemy Behavior – Different enemies interact with each other too (for example, crabs and butterflies have their own rules). Use these interactions to your advantage, possibly to thin out threats or collect extra diamonds.
 5. Manage Risk at the Exit – When you approach the exit door, double–check your diamond count. The door’s rule (“killIfOtherHasMore resource=diamond limit=9”) indicates that you must have your diamond resource at or below the allowed limit to successfully exit. If you’re over the limit, you might need to avoid or intentionally lose some diamonds before exiting.
 6. Exploit Environment Interactions – The level physics (including the “stepBack” reactions when collisions occur) give you clues on how different sprites behave. Learn these interactions to set up safe pathways and even create chain reactions that benefit you.

In summary, you’re playing an arcade–style puzzle–platformer where careful planning, resource management, and timing are key. Your goal is to explore the level safely while balancing the risk–reward of collecting diamonds and neutralizing enemies, then making it to the exit under the proper conditions.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT
4: ACTION_DOWN
5: ACTION_UP

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game. 

=== Sprite Mapping ===
avatar -> 'a'
background dirt -> '.'
background -> '-'
background exitdoor -> 'e'
background boulder -> 'o'
background diamond -> 'x'
background crab -> 'c'
background butterfly -> 'b'
boulder -> '@'
butterfly -> '#'
crab -> '$'
diamond -> '%'
dirt -> '&'
exitdoor -> '*'
wall -> 'b'
boulder butterfly -> 'd'

Action:4

I’ll attempt to move downward toward the exit door, expecting that if the first ACTION_DOWN only rotates the avatar, a second down move will actually clear the dirt in row10, col7 and help pave the way toward the door.
